item.title: 3D Printer Enclosure: Do You Need One?
item.description:
3D Printer Enclosure: Do You Need One?

You need a 3D printer enclosure if you print ABS, ASA, nylon, or polycarbonate. These filaments warp badly when they cool unevenly. An enclosure traps heat around your printer and keeps the temperature stable. If you only print PLA or PETG, you don’t need one.

That said, enclosures offer benefits beyond just warping prevention. Let’s cover when you actually need one, what your options are, and the safety stuff you can’t ignore.

item.title: ASA vs ABS: Which Filament Is Better for Outdoor Prints?
item.description:
This article may contain affiliate links. We may earn a small commission if you buy something through them, at no extra cost to you. We only recommend products we’d actually use ourselves.

ASA vs ABS: Which Filament Is Better for Outdoor Prints?

If you’re comparing ASA vs ABS filament for outdoor prints, ASA wins. It’s basically ABS with UV resistance built in. Parts printed in ASA hold up in direct sunlight for years without yellowing, cracking, or getting brittle. ABS degrades in UV light within months. For anything that lives outside, ASA is the right choice.

item.title: PLA vs PETG vs ABS: Complete Filament Comparison Guide
item.description:
PLA vs PETG vs ABS: Complete Filament Comparison Guide

If you’re comparing PLA vs PETG vs ABS, here’s the short answer. PLA is the easiest to print and best for beginners. PETG is stronger and more heat-resistant. ABS is the toughest but hardest to work with. The right choice depends on what you’re printing and where it’ll be used.

Let’s break down exactly how these three filaments compare so you can pick the right one for your project.
